data: Block of the local limestone, originally in situ above the entrance to the rock-cut structure of the gymnasium, but then cut from the site and removed. The epigraphic field is 212 x 64 cm. The face has two large round holes cut into the second line, and a further element cut out of the end of the first line (upper right corner). The lower edge is damaged, obscuring part of line 4.

Very regular neat v-cut letters. The text is centred on the stone. Note the use of horizontal lines/dashes between the name and patronym of the officials. Sigma is four bar and open; Pi has short second vertical; omicron and omega are small, the latter closed.
Probably Hieronian in date, given the letter forms and the content.
Found in situ, first observed in 1558.
Photographed in the museum by Prag, 2023.
Photo J. Prag, 02.03.2023, with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana

The museum was damaged in an earthquake and all the ancient archaeological material was sent to the Paolo Orsi for safe keeping. They have not yet been returned and the collection currently consists of stones from various medieval buildings, some medieval armour and weaponry, and 2 ancient inscribed blocks

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text checked against photograph (and rapid visual inspection);
  • 2: Manganaro: Ἀγαθ[άρχου]

English translation

Giorgia Capra

When Aristion son of Agath[---] and Philistion son of Epikrates were gymnasiarchs, the neaniskoi Hieroneioi (dedicated this).

Italian translation

Giorgia Capra

Quando Aristione figlio di Agath[---] e Filistione figlio di Epicrate erano ginnasiarchi, i neaniskoi Hieroneioi (dedicarono questo)

commentary

The text was first reported by Fazello in the 16th century, but removed from the site in 1894.

Block of the local limestone, originally in situ above the entrance to the rock-cut structure of the gymnasium, but then cut from the site and removed. The epigraphic field is 212 x 64 cm. The face has two large round holes cut into the second line, and a further element cut out of the end of the first line (upper right corner). The lower edge is damaged, obscuring part of line 4.

limestone block 74 212 48 chiselled

Very regular neat v-cut letters. The text is centred on the stone. Note the use of horizontal lines/dashes between the name and patronym of the officials. Sigma is four bar and open; Pi has short second vertical; omicron and omega are small, the latter closed.

Line 1-4 90 Interlineation line 1 to 2 Netum near Noto 36.94573, 15.02365 Probably Hieronian in date, given the letter forms and the content. Found in situ, first observed in 1558. Photographed in the museum by Prag, 2023.
